Award.AwardTitle: HCC: Multi-Finger High Fidelity Haptic Exploration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Imagine a virtual environment so realistic that within it one could practice a violin technique such as vibrato, or how to filet a freshly caught halibut, or a surgical procedure using patient specific data. Such applications, and countless others, would require a high quality haptic device for the hands through which realistic forces could be applied to convincingly simulate touch. Today's haptic interfaces - information technology that supports human touching and manipulation of virtual or remote objects - are still in their infancy compared to human haptic capabilities. The typical haptic device is connected to a single finger, or supports interaction through a pen-like stylus. In an effort to dramatically advance the state of the art, the PI has developed an exciting prototype multi-finger device of high resolution and bandwidth. In this project he will determine the limits of the prototype and refine the technology so that it is useful for evaluation in applications. To these ends, the PI will explore the requirements on high-fidelity haptic technology imposed by human perception. He will measure user thresholds {i.e., the smallest forces which they can perceive with multiple fingers), and will study multi-finger and bi-manual behavior and performance in exploring and manipulating objects and materials. These data will enable the PI to reconfigure his multi-finger haptic device and create software modifications as necessary, and also to develop a new haptic rendering algorithm and study how it interacts with human perception. Project outcomes will include engineering requirements for successful yet cost-effective haptic devices, along with some of the knowledge necessary to achieve future high quality multi-finger haptic interface applications

Broader Impacts: The technology to be developed in this project will ultimately give people who are visually impaired access to the many images and 3D datasets and models which are accessible only in electronic form. Additionally, haptics is an important enabling technology for medical simulations; better medical simulators will lead to fewer medical errors and more efficient training of medical personnel. Haptics is expected to have a significant impact on the appreciation and the conservation of works of art. Demonstrations of applications in these and other fields will be byproducts of this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Imagine a virtual environment so realistic that it can be used to practice a violin technique such as vibrato, ?letinga freshly caught halibut, or a non-routine open surgical procedure using patient speci?c data.   We are very farfrom that today. All of these applications, and countless others, require a high quality haptic (force feedback)device for the hands through which realistic forces are applied to convincingly simulate touch.
The goal of this research is to create some of the knowledge necessary to achieve high quality multi?nger hapticinterface applications. From our previous work, we now have an exciting prototype multi?nger device of highresolution and bandwidth — we need to ?nd its limits and make it useful for evaluation in applications.One of the signi?cant remaining problems of engineering haptic interfaces is rendering — computing feedbackforces in real time as a function of ?nger movement inputs. This computation grows in direct proportion to thenumber of ?ngers in the haptic display. We will aim to implement and characterize a novel rendering methodwhich uses bu?ering of polygons to achieve constant-time collision detection — a key element of the complexityof haptic rendering. A single memory cache of polygons will be re-used for all the ?ngers simultaneously.A second signi?cant problem, as with any haptic device (or for that matter any sensory display) is designingthe device in accordance with human perception. Haptic technology cannot be cost e?ective if it’s ?delityexceeds human sensory limitations. The appropriate sensory thresholds are not yet su?ciently known — espe-cially for multi?nger haptic devices. At a higher level, Lederman and Klatzky’s work showed speci?c patternsof human haptic data acquisition (exploratory procedures) which are routinely used for speci?c sensory tasks.To match a device to the human user at the psychological level, it should be compatible with EPs recognized byLederman and Klatzky. We would like to adapt the device to support as many EPs as possible and measure ifthis matching results in better haptic perception.
This project, which involved faculty, graduate and undergraduate students at the University of Washington, developed and published new results in high quality haptic interaction with multiple fingers.  We established an interesting collaboration with document conservators at the Library of Congress regarding the haptic properties of precision document conservation techniques.
